text:
Raskolnikov tapped Zametov on the shoulder. “I’m not mad, just being friendly. Like that worker of yours said when he was tussling with Dmitri about the old lady…”

“How do you know about that?” Zametov asked, surprised.

“Maybe I know more than you think.”

“You’re acting weird. You shouldn’t be out.”

“Do I seem strange?” Raskolnikov replied.

“Yes. Why are you reading the papers?”

“Yeah, I am.”

“Is it about the fires?”

“Nope, not reading about those.” He shot Zametov a sly look, smirking. “But admit it, you’re dying to know what I’m really reading about.”

“I’m not. Can I just ask why you keep…?”

“Listen, you’re a cultured guy, right?”

“I was in the sixth class at the gymnasium,” Zametov said, trying to sound important.

“Sixth class! Oh, my little bird! With your fancy hair and rings—you’re a real gentleman. Ugh, what a charming kid!” Raskolnikov burst out laughing, catching Zametov off guard. Zametov stepped back, more confused than offended.

“Wow, you’re really something!” Zametov said, still taken aback.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov engages in a cryptic conversation with Zametov, hinting at deeper thoughts while appearing unwell and strange.
